physDesc.p: This letter is 5 pages long (seq. 51-55). It is typed on good quality typing paper (neither notebook paper nor Lowell’s nice cardstock). The words “John Gould” are written in pencil across the top of the first page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your two letters came day before yesterday, and I was thankful to get them. You do not mention having been to Constable's, so I suppose you have forgotten that you gave me that as an address before you knew where you would be. If you have not been there yet, there must be a letter waiting for you.

You told me just what I wanted to know about the conditions in England. That placard in Trafalgar Square must be supremely ridiculous. In fact, I have been told by an English friend that somebody got up in the House of Parliament and said that it was making them a laughing-stock before the nations. But their earnestness and sobriety in pursuing this war is magnificent, and the fact that you feel it, is not at all surprising to me, for I am sure it is there.

Here things are moving much the same – creaking along rather than flowing, as usual at this season of the year. Richard has written that he cannot undertake to do the chronicle for Braithwaite, as he finds he will not be able to get any books or have any leisure for reading, and that Hilda, having taken on “The Egoist,” will not have time for it either. This is unfortunate, considering how hard I had to work to get Braithwaite to actually authorize me to ask him. Not that Braithwaite did not want to, but he is so procrastinating. However, I naturally have not done any complaining about this difficulty to Richard, as I do not want to make him feel that anything he does has put me out at all. He needs all his courage now, and all the affection and understanding we can all of us give him. Braithwaite behaved like a trump about it. That
man is the most loyal thing, barring yourself, I have yet struck! He instantly asked me to tell Richard that he should hold the position open for him when he returned from the war, and should get no one else to take it in the interval. But if I were you, I should take it informally while you are in England. I think an article on the state of poetry in England at this moment would be very acceptable to Braithwaite. However, please understand that I have not spoken to him about it and am not writing with his authority. They sold 2600 copies on the newsstands alone of the second number, which is pretty fine I think. I am going to ask Braithwaite if you subscribed, and if you did not, I shall subscribe for you, so that you may get the paper while you are abroad. They have got what I think is a really fine poem by Bodenheim in the next number.

I had a letter from William Carlos Williams this morning, asking me to send a poem for the August number of “Others,” which he is editing “pro tem.” I do not know whether Kreymborg is ill or away. I wrote and told him about our conversation with Kreymborg in New York, and said that, although I thought my original objections to “Others” had been more or less done away with by their more recent publications, nevertheless that you and I had made this agreement that we would stay out together, and that I could not therefore change. I like Williams, and I do not want him to be angry, and I wrote the letter as nicely as I could. “Others” comes out most uncertainly now that Marshall is publishing it, and I think there must be some hitch in Kreymborg’s “Mushrooms,” for I received a letter from Marshall – a personal letter signed with his name – two or three days ago, saying that he was enclosing a circular, and might he send me a few copies; and as I had already had a circular, without any letter, when the book first appeared, I can only assume that things are not going well there.

What is more important, I fear that Sandburg’s book is not selling very well either. They have entirely ceased to advertise it, and I have seen very few references to it in any paper. Of course, I do not get his
reviews, but there is nothing like the furor there was over “Spoon River” last year or over Frost’s books.

My own affairs are going remarkably smoothly. Lebowich tells me that they had a quantity of letters for and against the “Docket,” and he told Mr. Braithwaite he wished he could get another poem that produced so much of a sensation. A good many of the letters, I fear, were hostile, but I take all that in the day’s work now.

“Sword Blades” has just gone into another edition, to my intense satisfaction. I have agreed to speak before the Washington University Association in St. Louis on the 7th of November, giving the same lecture that I gave in Chicago last year; and they tell me that they may ask me later to repeat my four Chicago lectures in the Spring. I am also to repeat these four lectures at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, and I think I shall hire the Vendome and give them here on my own recognizances after my return from St. Louis.

Mrs. “Jack” Gardner has just caught on to us. I read her some of my things the other day at Bessie Perkin’s, and she has been raving about those Napoleonic pieces ever since. Now she is all agog – evidently thinks she has got hold of a new thing which it is very well worth while for her to know. You know she always likes to be in the swim. I am sending her your two books to-day. She will make an excellent advertising agent for us; nothing could be better.

I have sent “Malmaison” to Margaret Anderson, but I have not had a word in return. I do not know whether the duns have got her, or whether she is a little slow, or whether she does not like the poem. I sent five poems to “The Independent” the other day, and to my intense aston-
ishment they took them all, and said they would like a sketch of me by Frost on the opposite page. I do not think that Frost does this sort of thing, and I suggested Louis Untermeyer.

Richard writes me that Miss Weaver positively refused to print Jean Untermeyer’s “Clothes.” That is awfully embarrassing, as Richard accepted it, and I told her so. But the good Braithwaite instantly helped me out of the hole by accepting it himself.

I am enclosing a little clipping about you which came the other day. There are no reviews of any account yet. I have sent all I have got to Richard, so you can get them. The best one so far is by William Lyon Phelps and will appear in the July number of the “Poetry Review.” If Braithwaite only had some idea of choosing poetry, he could make that a good paper, for he has got a wonderful business hustler in that Jew.
I do hope you will come back in the Autumn, because I think the fruit is ripe, and you don’t want it to tumble to the ground and rot, because there is no one here to pick it.

I wish you would send me a sketch of your early life – of all your life, up to date – with anecdotes and things, for I am preparing my lectures along the line of my French lectures, and I want some biographical material

I suppose by the time you get this you will be married, in which case please remember me most kindly to your wife, and tell her that I hope we shall be great friends always and that I am very anxious to see her and welcome her into our little circle. Mrs. Russell has not yet come back, but I expect her a week from Sunday. It is beautiful here now, but very hot for the first time, and up to now it has done nothing but rain, day in and day out. I envy you being in England again, even in war time. One gets rather stale staying in the same place.

Bodenheim has departed, I think stealing his way to California on freight cars – that is the way he intended to go. He came round and told me a marvelous story of wishing to be there on June 15th, to stretch him-
self upon the grave of his beloved and vow to lead a better life. For this purpose, he needed $150.00, and he wished to sell two plays, with all the rights – “movie” and otherwise – for cash down, in order to get there; and he wanted to know if I knew anybody who would take the plays on these terms. Needless to remark, I did not, and I was not such a fool as to be “touched” for the hundred and fifty. But I gave him a cheque to cover the damageMary inflicted upon his overcoat, and I am sure that cheque will never go into a new coat; it will go into food and drink as long as it lasts. He was to let me know if he didn’t start, and as he has not let me know, I suppose he has gone. He read me an excellent poem, the best he has done I think, and I instantly told him to take it to Braithwaite; and then I rang up Braithwaite and told him how good the poem was, with the result that he accepted it; and it appears in the July number. I am afraid he did not get paid in advance, however; but they do pay on that paper, some months late, so he will get the money in the end.
I guess that is all my news, except that I miss our Sunday chats very much. Write again and often!
